title: Fortescue slams court for 'lowering bar' on native title
text:
Exclusive possession under native title effectively gives traditional owners the right to possess and occupy land to the “exclusion of all others”.

Fortescue believes that its exploration and mining leases prevail over the YAC’s exclusive possession of some 2700 square kilometres in Western Australia’s iron ore-rich Pilbara, including the company’s Solomon Mining hub.

However, it is worried about the standard the rulings set for establishing exclusive possession and the implication that might have for access to land in the future for miners and other industries.

Fortescue is also facing a compensation claim some have speculated could run to hundreds of millions of dollars and other fallout after being urged by WA's Labor government to back down in its row with YAC in the wake of the original court ruling by judge Steven Rares in 2017.

Five other Federal Court judges this month unanimously threw out Fortescue's appeal against the Rares ruling, which effectively meant the company built its Solomon hub without an agreement with the traditional owners.

Fortescue has less than three weeks to seek leave to take the case to the High Court and, if successful, push its legal battle with the Yindjibarndi into a twelfth year.

YAC chief executive Michael Woodley said the door remained open to negotiate with Fortescue but the company had not reached out since the appeal ruling so the Yindjibarndi continued to work on a compensation claim.

"We'll wait for the dust to clear on this front (possible High Court appeal). Once that is finished and we know where we stand, when there is no more avenue for Fortescue to appeal on this matter, then we'll submit our application for compensation," he said.

Mr Woodley has accused Fortescue of causing heartache in his community, including division in his own family, by backing a breakaway group known as Wirlu-murra Yindjibarndi Aboriginal Corporation (WMYAC) during the dispute.

Mr Woodley's brother, WMYAC member Davin Woodley, is now behind a request signed by more than 50 others for a general meeting of the WMYAC, which was awarded two Fortescue contracts worth $179 million in June.

The disgruntled WMYAC members are calling for fresh board elections and a forensic accounting report on all business dealings since 2010.

MMYAC did not respond to a request for comment.

Ms Gaines said Fortescue was considering its next move in the wake of losing the Federal Court appeal and remained open to concluding an Indigenous Land Use Agreement with the "whole of the Yindjibarndi community".

"Fortescue has never challenged the Yindjibarndi People’s right to native title, nor was this case ever about compensation," she said.

"Our mining tenure rights and current operations are also unaffected, and our legal advice is consistent with our previous view that there is no material financial impact to Fortescue following the Federal Court’s decision."

Ms Gaines also strongly defended Fortescue's record in negotiating with traditional owners and creating jobs and business opportunities for Aboriginal people.

Fortescue has seven Land Access Agreements in place with traditional owners which it says that in addition to royalties have delivered training and assistance to more than 1600 people and $2.3 billion in contracts to Aboriginal businesses.
description: Fortescue Metals Group has hit out at the Federal Court over native title rulings it claims pose a threat to investment in regional Australia.
